brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to observe whether people would report being less likely to sue
      a physician who shows more empathy when giving a patient potentially bad news regarding
      their medical condition.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Impact of Emergency Physician Empathy on Litigation Propensity

detailed_description.textblock:
The investigators hypothesized that patients will have less propensity to sue emergency
      physicians after a poor outcome if the physician demonstrated empathy by verbalizing that
      they recognize the patient is concerned about their symptoms, and that the patient knows
      their typical state of health better than a physician seeing them for the first time.
      Accordingly, the investigators will assess whether the presence or absence of emergency
      physician empathetic statements in videotaped simulated encounters will alter patient
      propensity towards litigation. Secondary objectives are to assess whether the presence or
      absence of empathetic statements alters patient perceptions of discharge instruction
      clarity, physician expertness, physician caring, and physician desirability.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Emergency Room Patient

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Non-English speaking

          -  Not healthy enough to be in waiting room

clinical_study.official_title: The Impact of Emergency Physician Empathy on Litigation Propensity

primary_outcome.description: This outcome will be assessed by asking "Would you sue this doctor?" after viewing a short video. Items will be measured on a 5-point scale (1=Definitely no to 5=Definitely yes).

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: This outcome will be assessed by asking "Do you believe this physician is an expert?" after viewing a short video. Items will be measured on a 5-point scale (1=Definitely no to 5=Definitely yes).

This outcome will be assessed by asking "Do you think this doctor cared about the patient?" after viewing a short video. Items will be measured on a 5-point scale (1=Definitely no to 5=Definitely yes).
This outcome will be assessed by asking "Would you want this physician as your doctor?" after viewing a short video. Items will be measured on a 5-point scale (1=Definitely no to 5=Definitely yes).
secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of whether subject would want to be physician's patient

secondary_outcome.description: This outcome will be assessed by asking "Did you understand the instructions the doctor gave the patient?" after viewing a short video. Items will be measured on a 5-point scale (1=Definitely no to 5=Definitely yes).
secondary_outcome.measure: Assessment of clarity of physician instructions

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective
